title: SAST Config UI Page - Basic SAST Wide Settings - Wire up GraphQL query to dynamic form
description:
This issue tracks the addition of the GraphQL query, and wiring it up to the form components, required to drive the [MVC design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228830).

## Implementation plan

* [x] Add GraphQL boilerplate to [application component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225974)
    - This will query the [`sastCiConfiguration`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/doc/api/graphql/reference/gitlab_schema.graphql#L9882-9885) entity for the given project on mounting.
* [x] Wire it up to the [dynamic form component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231370) in the template (pretty much just pass the `global` configuration entity array to it).
    - `input` event payload from dynamic form component _might_ need some transformation for form submission. The details are currently being discussed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220579#note_384633951.
* [x] Address review comments in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35866#note_384900046

epic.title: SAST Config UI Page - Basic SAST Wide Settings

title: SAST Config UI Page - Basic SAST Wide Settings - Implement dynamic form container control component
description:
This issue tracks the creation of the dynamic form container component that drives the [MVC design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228830).

This container component will create instances [child form components](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225224), based on the `type` of the configuration entity it's iterating over.

## Implementation plan

- [ ] Implement dynamic form component
    - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38162
    - Main prop will be an array of objects representing [SAST configuration entities](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/app/graphql/types/ci_configuration/sast/entity_type.rb). Each of these will be rendered by [child components](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225224) according to the `type` of the entity (for this iteration, only `string` needs to be considered).
    - Implementation will be *similar* to the `DynamicForm` component implemented described [here](https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/Validating-Schema-Driven-forms-with-Vuelidate/).
    - `v-model` bindings: `{ prop: 'entities', event: 'input' }`.
    - Event payload is modified copy of entities model. ~~Event payload will likely be something close to what is currently being discussed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220579#note_384633951, though this issue isn't _blocked_ by that discussion; i.e., a larger data structure which includes all configuration entities' current values.~~

title: Enable sast_configuration_ui feature flag by default
description:
This issue tracks the enablement of the `sast_configuration_ui` feature flag, and the addition of documentation for SAST Config UI.

The work to implement the [SAST Configuration UI](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3659#implementation-plan) for %13.3 is being carried out under the `sast_configuration_ui` feature flag. Once the feature is implemented as described in that epic, the feature flag should be enabled, and the documentation added.

It will be removed completely by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235135.

## Implementation plan

- [x] Enable the feature flag by default in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/ee/app/controllers/projects/security/sast_configuration_controller.rb#L34
- [x] Add documentation. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216635#note_368549459.

title: Design Update: Reorganize Threat Management Tabs
description:
## Summary

<!--
Please briefly describe what part of the code base needs to be refactored.
-->

The new Alerts tab is likely to be more important for users than the current Overview tab.  The plan is to rename the Overview tab as the Statistics tab and move it to the end.  We will come back and create a new Overview tab later (maybe in 2021) and continue to add more detailed statistics information to the Statistics tab.

## Implementation Steps

See Improvements below.


## Improvements

<!--
Explain the benefits of refactoring this code.
See also https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/index.html#say-why-not-just-what
-->
* The current Security & Compliance -> Threat Monitoring -> Overview tab will be renamed "Statistics"
* The Security & Compliance -> Threat Monitoring tabs will be reordered as follows:
  * Alerts
  * Policies
  * Statistics
* When users navigate to Security & Compliance, the default tab that is open will be the Alerts tab

## Designs

![update](/uploads/c6b6e5dcb9d419f5714c477e4c69413a/update.png)

title: Create CI Lint API endpoint scoped to project
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37134 we expanded the CI Lint to use a `dry run` mode which goes deeper in the pipeline creation stack, providing a simulation of the actual pipeline creation.

The `dry run` mode was implemented only for `Projects::Ci::LintsController#create` while the API endpoint still uses the legacy method via `YamlProcessor`. Converting the existing API endpoint to use `dry run` is not possible because it's project agnostic. The `dry run` is project-aware.

To solve this problem we could introduce a new API endpoint scoped to projects: `POST v4/projects/:id/ci/lint` which would have `dry run` on by default.

This endpoint should return:

```ruby
{ 
  status: 'failed', # or success
  errors: [ ... ],
  warnings: [ ... ],
  jobs: [ ... ] # if status: success
}
```

title: Optional merge request approvals do not send email notifications
description:
### Summary

gitlab-org/gitlab#27426 introduced the optional approve button for the GitLab Core edition. However approve action does not send any e-mail notifications or todo-list item unlike the approvals on the Gitlab EE.

It would be nice to be able to receive the notifications in form of either email or todo list item.

### Steps to reproduce

- Have a Gitlab CE installation
- Start a merge request
- Approve it

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

- No email or to-do item is created which means I don't know at all when reviewer approves my change unless I visit it.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

- I get email notification that merge request xyz was approved

title: Fix parallel jobs dropdown from cutting off in the pipeline graph
description:
### Summary When on the pipeline graph page where we can see every job, there might be instances where the dropdown that list all of the parallel jobs gets cut off at the bottom. This is because the dropdown html element is inside the pipeline graph container, but the container might be to small to render the full dropdown. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a yml file with a single job that is divided in multiple parallel job (10+ for very easy reproduction) 2. Run any pipeline 3. Go to `/pipelines/$ID` by clicking on the pipeline ID (You should be seeing the pipeline graph) 4. Click on the job to expand all of its parallel tasks. 5. Notice that the dropdown does out of bound and is cut off. ### Example Project https://gitlab.com/jyavorska/testci/-/pipelines/170008449 ### What is the current *bug* behavior? The dropdown is cut off ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? Show the full dropdown no matter the size of the pipeline container ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-23_at_10.34.07_AM](/uploads/74b0e0c7be04258de6cf34f81f767600/Screen_Shot_2020-07-23_at_10.34.07_AM.png) ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/1e35547aaf085514f2df175486b20493545b9e3b/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/components/graph/graph_component.vue#L127-128 On line 127, we define the pipeline graph container, and the dropdown is inside this container. We should make it so that the dropdown doesn't render in the container (and is therefore nor tied in to its height) or have the minimum height of the container equal the height of the job list, though this is a bit more flaky and complex.

title: Test suite detail endpoint returns 404 for url containing a /
description:
### Summary

Test suite detail endpoint returns a `404` when the url contain a `/`.

| Bad URL | Good URL |
| ------ | ------ |
| [rspec system pg/24.json](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines/169992149/tests/rspec%20system%20pg/8.json?build_ids[]=653055162&build_ids[]=653055146&build_ids[]=653055152&build_ids[]=653055130&build_ids[]=653055127&build_ids[]=653055132&build_ids[]=653055140&build_ids[]=653055166&build_ids[]=653055123&build_ids[]=653055156&build_ids[]=653055120&build_ids[]=653055188&build_ids[]=653055134&build_ids[]=653055133&build_ids[]=653055119&build_ids[]=653055131&build_ids[]=653055172&build_ids[]=653055125&build_ids[]=653055190&build_ids[]=653055143&build_ids[]=653055129&build_ids[]=653055122&build_ids[]=653055137&build_ids[]=653055121) | [rspec system pg.json](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines/169992149/tests/rspec%20system%20pg.json?build_ids[]=653055162&build_ids[]=653055146&build_ids[]=653055152&build_ids[]=653055130&build_ids[]=653055127&build_ids[]=653055132&build_ids[]=653055140&build_ids[]=653055166&build_ids[]=653055123&build_ids[]=653055156&build_ids[]=653055120&build_ids[]=653055188&build_ids[]=653055134&build_ids[]=653055133&build_ids[]=653055119&build_ids[]=653055131&build_ids[]=653055172&build_ids[]=653055125&build_ids[]=653055190&build_ids[]=653055143&build_ids[]=653055129&build_ids[]=653055122&build_ids[]=653055137&build_ids[]=653055121) |

### Steps to reproduce

1. Visit the pipeline page
2. Click on the test tab
3. Click any test suite containing a `/` in the name

### Example Project

The feature is currently behind a feature flag on `gitlab.com`.

You can see the bug on this [example pipeline](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines/169984763/test_report).

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The endpoint returns a `404` response.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The endpoint returns a `200` response.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Pipeline___GitLab.org___GitLab___GitLab_2020-07-23_10-09-28](/uploads/2892c3dab8792bd4c0780a17f996f3c3/Pipeline___GitLab.org___GitLab___GitLab_2020-07-23_10-09-28.png)

### Possible fixes

We could strip out the last part of the URL and remove everything after the `/`.

cc @shampton @rickywiens @samdbeckham

title: Refactor pipelines controller create method
description:
Let's refactor [PipelinesController#create](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/controllers/projects/pipelines_controller.rb#L63) to respond in `JSON` format. 

Currently behind the feature flag `new_pipeline_form` we have rebuilt `pipelines/new` view to use a [Vue app](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35674) to create pipelines. It's currently using the public API but there is a discrepancy between the API and the controller. Specifically the `only` values of `:api` and `:web`. Which will not allow us to use the public API.

Once the BE part of this issue is complete. We will need to refactor the FE part of this feature to use the controller rather than the public API.

NOTE: We need to be sure the inline JS in [`app/views/projects/pipelines/new.html.haml`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/projects/pipelines/new.html.haml) is removed as part of this effort. If this is not possible, we chould create a follow up issue to track that removal

title: audit_json.log serializes ip_address into JSON object
description:
`audit_json.log` appears to be serializing `ip_address` as an object with `family`, `addr`, and `mask_addr` instead of just a simple string, which is causing Elasticsearch to reject these entries:

```json
{   
   "severity":"INFO",
   "time":"2020-07-23T13:34:09.205Z",
   "correlation_id":"34IGPTSPB7",
   "id":null,
   "author_id":1954985,
   "entity_id":18869427,
   "entity_type":"Project",
   "details":{
      "author_name":"redacated",
      "target_id":310428,
      "target_type":"ApprovalProjectRule",
      "target_details":"anyone master",
      "custom_message":"Added User X to approval group on anyone master rule",
      "ip_address":null,
      "entity_path":"redacted"
   },
   "created_at":"2020-07-23T13:34:09.185Z",
   "ip_address":{
      "family":2,
      "addr":1300105045,
      "mask_addr":4294967295
   },
   "author_name":"redacted",
   "entity_path":"redacted",
   "target_details":null
}
```

@smcgivern @mwoolf I think this was partially fixed in !35356 (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/224539), but only in the presenter. If I look at the database entry, it seems we are storing an `IPAddr` object here? It seems to me we shouldn't do that?

```ruby
[ gprd ] production> proj.audit_events.last
=> #<SecurityEvent id: 346169840, author_id: 1954985, type: "SecurityEvent", entity_id: 18869427, entity_type: "Project", details: {:author_name=>"Nadav", :target_id=>310429, :target_type=>"ApprovalProjectRule", :target_details=>"second eye", :custom_message=>"Added User X to approval group on second eye rule", :ip_address=>nil, :entity_path=>"redacted"}, created_at: "2020-07-23 13:34:09", ip_address: #<IPAddr: IPv4:77.126.7.85/255.255.255.255>, author_name: "edacted", entity_path: "redacted", target_details: nil>
```

title: Add context that Code Quality Tab shows full report for source branch
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

As a user on the pipeline page, I want to know which code quality issues are from my change, so I can focus on the code I just wrote and don't introduce more issues/bugs/problems trying to fix 8000 things.

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer) - who has no context of what all these issues are.

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

The user should get some context on the full code quality tab that this list is ALL issues for the source branch, not just their change.

### Proposal

* Add some context (via text probably) as an interim step before we tackle the ability to filter by files in the current MR.
* **Text to add -** "This report contains all Code Quality issues in the source branch."

Longer term this lack of context will be addressed with functionality in the [Full Code Quality Report enhancements](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3500).

title: Simplify MR error state calculation
description:
## Problem to solve

The ~frontend receives a bunch of input parameters about the MR state instead of the end result after all parameters are combined. This requires the frontend to have complex business logic to determines an MR's error state based on all parameters received.

## Proposal

We can do two things to make this easier:

1. Move this to the ~backend 
    - We should have all business logic in the backend.
    - Having a complex branching logic around this isn't ideal, but it helps isolate the technical debt and shift the load off frontend.
2. Simplify the calculation of the error state (maybe have an enum for it or even a state machine if that makes sense)

title: User private profile enabled by default
description:
## Problem to solve

GitLab does not provide the possibility of creating new users with the private profile enabled by default. In different organizations, this might bring new features for data privacy. This is to comply with local data privacy laws and the agreements with, e.g. a company's works council.

It is important that new users "at first" have no choice as to how their profile is set up. It must first be set private. Later, every user can decide for themselves whether to make their profile public or keep it private.

## Intended users

Any new user just registered for the first time in GitLab

## Proposal

Make this an instance setting to use private profile enabled by default for any new accounts. Users have the option to override this setting later in their profile page. So, even if the instance setting is set to `false`, the user profile will be created as a private profile when they start off, but they can later switch it to a public profile themselves.

The admin, when they create a new user via the UI/API should respect this instance setting.

When an admin sends a POST request to `/users` with `private_profile=false` (when the instance setting is `true`) to create a new user, the response should be successful, and the value of the instance setting should be overridden by the value present in the API params.

## Implementation Plan

* Migration to add a new boolean column in `ApplicationSetting`, `default_to_private_profile`, with a default value of `false`
* Allow to change this value via the instance admin UI/API
* New users should inherit this boolean value to `User#private_profile` upon creation

## Availability and Testing

* The E2E test `qa/qa/specs/features/browser_ui/1_manage/user/follow_user_activity_spec.rb` will also need to be updated within this issue. This test uses 2 users- a `followed_user` and `following_user`, where the `followed_user` performs various actions (creating a project, MR, issue, etc.) and the `following_user` visits the `followed_user` profile to verify the correct user activity displays. We need to ensure the `followed_user`'s profile will be set to public.
  * Add a `data-qa-selector` to the "Private profile - Don't display activity-related personal information on your profile." checkbox element on the user's profile settings page
  * Create a new page module to represent a user's main profile settings page (ex: `qa/qa/page/profile/show.rb`)
  * Add the element reference to this page module and create method(s) that toggle the user's profile to private or public
  * Make changes to `follow_user_activity_spec` to log in as the `followed_user` and use the new method to set their profile to public first before continuing on with the test
  * Feel free to reach out to @vburton with any questions

title: Extract variables builder from project/pipeline/build classes
description:
## Description

We want to optimize the workflow of calculating build variables, as per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213560 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/22520.

In order to make it easier to optimize calculating build variables, we might want to extract variables builder, to a separate class / module. This will make it easier to profile this code, and find deficiencies.

### Problem 1 - from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213560

When calling `Ci::CreatePipelineService`, N jobs are created, as specified in the `.gitlab-ci.yml` file. Each of these jobs has a number of environment variables set, and whether the job should be created or not can sometimes *depend* on the value of these variables. Many of the variables are identical for every job in the pipeline; a small number vary between jobs in the same pipeline.

I'm not *too* familiar with the CI areas of the codebase, but to me it looks like we build the list of variables at least once per job. I put a few debugging `puts` statements into `Project#predefined_variables` and elsewhere, created a new pipeline based on GitLab's own `.gitlab-ci.yml`, and got this output:

```
</details>

(note that this is *with* `RequestStore` enabled).

The cost of generating these variables is quite, um, variable. Some are backed by database columns in the same model currently holding the code; some go to associated records (which can be expensive with repeated calls, e.g.: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28688 ); others make calls to Gitaly, the results of which may or may not be cached in redis, RequestStore, or instance variables. We see that creating a pipeline can be very slow for GitLab.com, and I think this is at least part of why - repeatedly generating the CI variables is not cheap.

### Problem 2 - from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/22520

`Ci::Build#scoped_variables` is responsible for returning all predefined variables that are going to be set in a runner environment.

It is quite slow, it takes around 2s on my local machine, a little more on production currently.

We are calling Gitaly three times there, and there is probably some room for optimization.

## Proposal (done in 1st iteration - see next steps)

Extract `Ci::Variables::Builder` class or module. Use dependency injection to manage dependencies on objects that are required to calculate variables like project / pipeline / build etc.

Ensure that we can remove duplicate computations with memoization. For example, we should be able to use the same builder for multiple builds in a pipeline to make the most of memoization.

Expected improvements:
- we should have the logic to compute CI variables in one place
- easy to memoize variables (e.g. group, project, pipeline variables) across multiple builds
- easy to profile and make further improvements when needed 

**Merge Request in progress**: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52800

## Next steps

1. [x] Enable the FF introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/72348 & measure results
1. [ ] Add more variables into the builder, with feature flags, repeating what we did in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/72348.
1. [ ] Plan is pretty much what is described here https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/71439#note_702509482
1. [ ] Over time we should see a decline in the time taken to build these scoped_variables. As measured by the `gitlab_ci_pipeline_builder_scoped_variables_duration` prometheus metric.
1. [ ] Move more variables into the builder, such that `Build#variables` can be fully moved into a builder object.

## Testing

Please make sure `package-and-qa` pass in implementation MR.

epic.title: Pipeline creation is slow

title: Security scanning results are misleading
description:
## Summary

When creating a MR that has security vulnerabilities, it says "scanner detected # **new** severity vulnerabilities". However, it's a list of vulnerabilities currently in the code base, not new vulnerabilities introduced with the MR. This is causing confusion because people think they introduced new vulnerabilities with their MR. We should remove the word **new** to reduce confusion.

The source file is `ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/security_reports/grouped_security_reports_app.vue`.

## Problem to solve

With the change introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/221084, the merge request now shows a highly visible warning for security vulnerabilities. However, these can sometimes be incorrectly indicated as `new` even though the changed file could not have introduced them (e.g. changing CSS or markdown). This creates confusion for maintainers and reviewers who could believe by merging a minor change they are introducing new security vulnerabilities. As it stands, what is really presented is a list of all findings currently present in the branch—even if the change was not the source of introduction.

It is important that the merge widget only show clear and accurate information so that it can be trusted by authors, reviewers and maintainers. This has become worse in recent releases because of the new visual treatment which highlights vulnerabilities even more.

![2020-07-23T16.54.55](/uploads/a0e48e93617d48d8961f3b30210f1811/2020-07-23T16.54.55.png)

## Further details

First reported in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217311


## Proposal

To address the immediate confusion, removing the word `new` introduced in the recent change will more accurately reflect that branches contain vulnerabilities but did not necessarily introduce them. This will satisfy the core issue highlighted here.

There are other, related challenges with data quality and consistency that are not the specific problem here but do need to be addressed to improve the quality and trustworthiness of the security MR widget. These will be collected and tracked in [a separate Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4013).

title: Expose Note against Timelog from API
description:
!35916 introduced an optional `note_id` field into a timelog. If the timelog was created via quick action with no other text, e.g.

```
/spend 1h
```

there is no `note_id` since there is no note created. However, if the timelog was created in a note with text, such as

```
This turned out to be easy so it didn't take as much time as I thought.
/spend 1h
```

the new note's `note_id` is persisted in the timelog.

Do we need to add this new bit of information to any views? :thinking: 

edit: It needs to be added to the API

----

The following discussion from !35916 should be addressed:

- [ ] @engwan started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35916#note_383565260):  (+3 comments)

    > The tests passed :tada:
    > 
    > @cablett can you do maintainer review for this?
    > 
    > The changes here were suggested by me so it would be nice for someone else to take a look. It's not ideal but I think it's the cleanest way to do it without redesigning our quick action DSL / service to have a reference to the persisted object? :thinking:

title: Remove confirm email from trial form
description:
## Problem 
 
When a net-new user signs up for a SaaS trial they first signup for GitLab and then are redirected to the trial form. When they are redirected to the trial form, we display two banners `Welcome! You have signed up successfully` and a second banner to `Confirm your email address` which directs them to their inbox to confirm their email. 
 
If a user follows this path and goes to their inbox and clicks the confirmation link it brings them directly into the product skipping the remaining steps in the trial flow at which point the user has a free account. 
 
Since we don't track user_id it's impossible to quantify the number of users that sign up and go through this specific flow but we have received a [report](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/marketing/marketing-operations/-/issues/3275) of a user "confused because they never got their trial" which I believe is from them going through this exact pattern. 
 
| Trial user experience coming through signup | Experience after clicking within the confirmation email |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_2.43.46_PM](/uploads/a45901d18c07fe510d568a495f99fe86/Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_2.43.46_PM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_2.57.13_PM](/uploads/b27d23dafb6a202f04501b8bae00ca2f/Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_2.57.13_PM.png) |
| User experience when it's a net-new user signing up for a trial that just created their GitLab account | The experience if a user follows the banner instructions and goes ahead and clicks the link in the confirmation email |

 
## Proposed solution 
 
We remove both banners from all steps in the trial flow. A user will still get the confirmation email and future banners in the product to confirm their email. By removing these banners we will reduce the cognitive load on the page and therefore should see an increase in the completion rate on the trial form.

title: Rename `Scanner` in Vulnerability Report and Vulnerability Details to `Tool`
description:
### Summary We currently miscategorize `Scan Type` as `Scanner` on the vulnerability report both in the table and filters. The "Scan Type" should be our categories such as `sast` or `dependency scanning` where-as the "Scanner" refers to the underlying tool reporting the findings; i.e. `gosec` or `gemnasium`. This can be confusing and is incongruent with the vulnerability details page, where we list the scanner correctly (see screenshot below) See Secure Glossary MR for more on the distinction: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/49901/diffs Additionally, there will be future sources of vulnerability data that does not come from a scanner/pipeline job. For example, we will soon have the ability to add vulnerability objects by manually creating them or doing so directly via API. This adds further weight to `Scanner` being an inappropriate name for the vulnerability source. To be more clear and more inclusive, we will instead rename this column to `Tool`. ### Steps to reproduce Visit https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/security/vulnerability_report and look at column ### Example Project https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/security/vulnerability_report ### What is the current behavior? We display the "Scan Type" under the heading of "Scanner" ### What is the desired behavior? We display the filter for report type and column with the updated heading of "Tool" ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots #### Vulnerability list ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_10.41.05_AM](/uploads/6cd90ca7d62d23587ce6c4a8e0b6b008/Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_10.41.05_AM.png) #### Vulnerability Details ![image](/uploads/6b805c92e5df37c85779b38602032949/image.png) ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes - [ ] Rename "Scanner" column to "Tool": || |-| |![ksnip_20210615-150725](/uploads/f82b67e34001d66f9b33480af3e16b58/ksnip_20210615-150725.png)| - [ ] Rename all instances of the word "scanner" to "tool" for the scanner dropdown: || |-| |![](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/b20b4f99795ff23d0382598de9d83b4d/ksnip_20210611-142507.png)| (If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem) - [ ] Update documentation screenshots and references to the scanner filter.

title: Use gl-friendly-wrap in test_suite_table
description:
## Overview
In !37249 we added a wrap class to the JUnit report table in order to display the entire suite name and class name in the table, as opposed to truncating it. An improvement to our approach would be to use the `<gl-friendly-wrap>` element instead of performing the change in CSS directly. 

As a frontend engineer, we should use the `<gl-friendly-wrap>` component to ensure consistency across the code base and allow us to universally apply changes to word-wrap as opposed to requiring engineers to look for all occurrences of word-wrap when a change is desired.

## Proposal
As discussed [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37249#note_383937933) we should use the `<gl-friendly-wrap>` component in the table rows for the JUnit test report. We should tell the component that it is preferable to wrap on the following symbols: `::`, `#`, `.`, `_`, `-`, `/`, `\`

## Context
<details>
The following discussion from !37249 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pslaughter started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37249#note_383937933): 

    > **suggestion (non-blocking):** You'll notice in the screenshots that the text is wrapped at some non-ideal places:
    > 
    > ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_12.07.29_PM](/uploads/e8f7ec7d682136814caabe0090cc5b8d/Screen_Shot_2020-07-22_at_12.07.29_PM.png)
    > 
    > This is actually a problem we've run into before and solved with [a cool `<gl-friendly-wrap>` component](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/utilities-friendly-wrap--default) kudos to @pgascouvaillancourt! Let's create a follow up to use that component here so we can present a friendlier wrapping :smile:
    > 
    > I'll create this issue :eyes:

</details>

title: Remove the x-y-stable jobs from Security Products CI configs
description:
### Problem to solve

As we've [replaced `x-y-stable` docker images with `major` tag for Security Products](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/207128), we no longer need some CI configurations in several projects.

### Intended users

~"devops::secure" team members

### Implementation plan

1. Update our projects CI configuration that still contains job definitions to build `x-y-stable` docker images to remove them: 

- [x] ~~[sast](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/sast)~~ (archived)
- [x] ~~[dependency-scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning)~~ (archived)
- [x] [license-management](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management) projects.
- [x] Please double check for possibly other impacted projects.
  - [x] `x-y-stable` jobs were removed from Container Scanning in [Use shared CI analyzer template ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/merge_requests/17)

There's no need to update the CI configuration of `sast` and `dependency-scanning` since these 2 projects have been archived.

:warning: Do not delete existing images! :warning:

### Documentation

- [x] update https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/release/-/blob/master/docs/release_process.md
   - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/release/-/merge_requests/84

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

CI configs are cleaned up.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

- ~"group::composition analysis" 
- ~"group::static analysis" 

### Links / references

### Testing

The test pipelines of affected projects with edited CI configs should provide a regression test that the analyser is functioning correctly with the image being brought down.

title: Allow users to create a new label list within an epic board
description: ### Problem to solve > When facilitating planning at scale across many teams or groups within my organization, I want a high level view of how my epics are moving through a workflow, so that I can track and report on the progress of features and initiatives. How might we allow users to create new label lists within their epic board so that they may create more workflow stages for their epics? ### User experience goal Users can craft workflows for their epics to better track their work. ### Proposal **Figma:** https://www.figma.com/file/epYXyMqBv0LdJ5F2coAMTf/and-2864-Program-boards?node-id=128%3A15621 - The `Add list` dropdown triggers the `Add list from label` dropdown that currently exists within issue boards as well. - The user can select an existing label, create a new one and select it, or manage their labels- as is consistent with the current experience. - Other list options are not MVC. ### Documentation ### Availability & Testing ### What does success look like, and how can we measure that? Users are crafting workflow lists. We could track how many lists they create and possibly patterns around naming conventions to allow us to better suggest defaults.

title: Deleted Projects not being properly deleted
description:
### Summary

Deleting a project causes the project not to be entirely deleted.

### Steps to reproduce

* Create project
* Set for [adjourned](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223013) deletion
* Wait for adjourned deletion to occur
* Attempt to load project - it will load

### Example Project

(If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report)

(If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version)

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Project still loads after apparent deletion but with no data:

![image](/uploads/42a0671b0a04ac35a1a66c6e747b937a/image.png)

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Project does not load after deletion.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/discover/doc/AW5F1e45qthdGjPJueGO/pubsub-rails-inf-gprd-003219?id=c6gvcnMBczpL6wEeiwOb

### Output of checks

(If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com)

### Possible fixes

When deletion is attempted, SQL errors are raised that prevent the full deletion sequence.  Example:

```
[ gprd ] production> p.delete_error 
=> "PG::QueryCanceled: ERROR:  canceling statement due to statement timeout\nCONTEXT:  SQL statement \"DELETE FROM ONLY \"public\".\"ci_pipelines_config\" WHERE $1 OPERATOR(pg_catalog.=) \"pipeline_id\"\"\n"
```

title: [BE] Return all snippet blobs in JSON requests
description:
As we're doing with embedding snippet files in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/39279, we need to update `SnippetActions#show` to return all snippets blobs in JSON requests instead of just one file.

The modification would be something like:

```diff
diff --git a/app/controllers/concerns/renders_blob.rb b/app/controllers/concerns/renders_blob.rb
index b8026c7a01d..638017a3796 100644
--- a/app/controllers/concerns/renders_blob.rb
+++ b/app/controllers/concerns/renders_blob.rb
@@ -28,6 +28,18 @@ module RendersBlob
     render json: json
   end

+  def render_blobs_json(blobs)
+    return render_404 if blobs.empty?
+
+    values = []
+
+    blobs.each do |blob|
+      values << blob_json(blob)
+    end
+
+    render json: values
+  end
+
   def conditionally_expand_blob(blob)
     blob.expand! if params[:expanded] == 'true'
   end
diff --git a/app/controllers/concerns/snippets_actions.rb b/app/controllers/concerns/snippets_actions.rb
index bb9db410d90..b8c86715366 100644
--- a/app/controllers/concerns/snippets_actions.rb
+++ b/app/controllers/concerns/snippets_actions.rb
@@ -67,8 +67,9 @@ module SnippetsActions
       end

       format.json do
-        conditionally_expand_blob(blob)
-        render_blob_json(blob)
+        @blobs = @snippet.blobs
+        conditionally_expand_blobs(@blobs)
+        render_blobs_json(@snippet.blobs)
       end

       format.js do
```

title: Use GlTruncate instead of css word wrap in the Vulnerability List Description column
description:
## Context 

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217961 was an issue to fix the text overflow in the vulnerability list component. In cases where the file path was long, it was causing a text overlap with other columns/components. The quick fix was to wrap text so that it goes into multiple lines.

## Description

As mentioned in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217961#note_383134415, now we have a component (see related issue here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/-/issues/767) that truncates long text. 

Let's use this component to truncate long texts in the vulnerability list instead of wrapping it.

## Implementation plan

- [ ] Remove the `tdClass: 'gl-word-break-all'` definition in ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/vulnerability_list.vue
- [ ] Use the new `GlTruncate` component instead: https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/utilities-truncate--default

title: Enrich data in Unknown sign-in Email
description:
Currently, we send out an email if a user signs in from an unknown location/device.

It looks like this currently:

![Screenshot_2020-07-22_at_3.18.46_PM](/uploads/d1aa8637301c907bacea76db117fdd0f/Screenshot_2020-07-22_at_3.18.46_PM.png)

Problem:

There isn't much actionable info here so as to take a decision. Most people do not know what their IP address is of the top of their head, so just providing this information and asking "is this you?" might not always be fruitful.

Requested change:

Enrich this data by including more details such as the Device Data, Browser Data etc to quickly identify the device used to login. We could also consider adding the approximate location based on IP address, in another iteration (using something like: http://www.rubygeocoder.com/).

### Problem to solve

When migrating from another product it may be useful to add historical data that is currently in progress, or just to move all the data over to keep it in a single location. For this to work Iterations need to support having dates in the past.

title: DAST scan rules added to `DAST_EXCLUDE_RULES`are shown as PASS in the logs.
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When `DAST_EXCLUDE_RULES` is used to exclude scan rules from running, the logs show the rules as runs, which is indicated as `PASS`. This could be confusing to user who consults the logs, as this gives a wrong impression that the disabled rules are run even though it is not.
### Steps to reproduce

1.  Set 
```
variables:
    DAST_EXCLUDE_RULES: "10048"
```
2. In the logs it shows
```
 PASS: Remote Code Execution - Shell Shock [10048]
```

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/648092551

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Scan rules that are excluded to run using `DAST_EXCLUDE_RULES` is shown as run in the log. e.g. `PASS: Remote Code Execution - Shell Shock [10048]`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The Scan rules that are excluded to run using `DAST_EXCLUDE_RULES` should be indicated as SKIP in the logs as it's not executed e.g `SKIP: Remote Code Execution - Shell Shock [10048]`

### Implementation Plan

- [x] The name of the policy used to return the active scan rules should not be [hardcoded](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/97d65902683537fccf1e9a9cffa3288de69d50e7/src/zap_gateway/zaproxy.py#L129)
- [x] Add an end-to-end test to verify that the passive and active scan rules logged are correct
- [x] Filter rules by those that are active (if necessary) before printing to the log
- [x] Ensure that excluded passive and active scan rules are not printed in the log
- [x] Show skipped rules in the log
- [x] Refactor `ExecutedRules` to `Rules`, `ExecutedRule` to `Rule`, `printer.ExecutedRules` to `services.Summary`
- [x] Add a changelog entry
- [x] Passive scan rules that are skipped should be logged as such in the log file, for example, `10027` in the `test_webgoat_full_scan`

title: Gitlab::Middleware::Multipart bypass to leak some files in object storage
description:
**[HackerOne report #927953](https://hackerone.com/reports/927953)** by `ledz1996` on 2020-07-20:

### Summary

The mitigation for #850447 lack the check for `remote_id` for file uploading param inside a hash. For example I could slip in `remote_id` if the upload parameter is inside a Hash, such as `user[avatar]`

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enable Object Storage for Uploads

```/etc/gitlab/gitlab.rb  
gitlab_rails['uploads_storage_path'] = "/opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-rails/public"  
gitlab_rails['uploads_base_dir'] = "uploads/-/system"  
gitlab_rails['uploads_object_store_enabled'] = true  
# gitlab_rails['uploads_object_store_direct_upload'] = true  
gitlab_rails['uploads_object_store_background_upload'] = true  
# gitlab_rails['uploads_object_store_proxy_download'] = false  
gitlab_rails['uploads_object_store_remote_directory'] = "lfsgit-ducanh"  
gitlab_rails['uploads_object_store_connection'] = {  
   'provider' => 'AWS',  
   'region' => 'ap-southeast-1',  
   'aws_access_key_id' => 'Redacted',  
   'aws_secret_access_key' => 'Redacted'  
 }  
```

2. Login as an user  
3. For testing upload a file with PNG extension or any extension as long as the content of the file is matched to `png, gif, ico, jpeg, tiff`  and size under 200kb to  bucket specified in the config, in my case it is `lfsgit-ducanh` under folder `tmp/uploads`  
4. Intercept the request send to upload user avatar modify the  following:  
param `user[avatar]` to `user[avatar`  
Add the following param to multipart:  
param `user[avatar][.remote_id]` with value as the name of the file upload  
param `user[avatar][.size]` to 1  
param `user[avatar][.name]` to `test.png`

Sample request:

title: Create links widget frontend
description:
### Problem to solve

During incidents, there is often conversation happening in other places, for example in zoom or in Slack. While we do have pinned embeds for surfacing Zoom calls, the feature isn't discoverable (can only be used if you happen to know there is a slash command for adding the zoom link). Can we better surface links to other relevant communication channels within incidents?

### Intended users

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)

### User experience goal
Allow users to quickly see and access important links that are relevant to quickly resolving an incident.

### Proposal
Following the pattern for the "Related issues" widget, introduce a "Resource Links" widget to incident issues. Though the use case is strictly for adding links to associated communications channels, by keeping the widget generic enough, people could also use this space to link to other relevant resources, for example, links to Runbooks, relevant dashboards, etc. Here's how this could look:

| Links widget | Links widget expanded | Link added | Adding links when there is an existing link | Tooltip |
| ------ | ------ |  ------ | ------ | ------ | 
|![Links_widget](/uploads/6b99c1b83c861e549130335a7d86c6e6/Links_widget.png) | ![Links_expanded](/uploads/7cc0ee4d20ab42d0ddfa195b415af1f3/Links_expanded.png) | ![Link_added](/uploads/e5408d390e4c827c8bae43d9736a4da2/Link_added.png)|![Added_with_existing_link](/uploads/563615b08ec6bb84ac7e76df4daa4146/Added_with_existing_link.png)|![Tooltip](/uploads/62e1cd67a1cc34a37422bd86df1e114d/Tooltip.png)|

[Prototype](https://www.figma.com/proto/N1r3VH8fTH950AvUtpGRNd/Sidebar-links-for-widgets-gitlab-com%26230852?node-id=493%3A24715&scaling=min-zoom&page-id=493%3A24464&starting-point-node-id=493%3A24715)

**_Note: the related issue and related merge request widgets are currently being unboxed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/87886. We should plan on matching the styling of this new links widget to whatever work is done in that MR._**

If we're implementing it after that MR moves forward, this is how it would look:

| Links widget | Links widget expanded | Link added | Adding links when there is an existing link | Tooltip |
| ------ | ------ |  ------ | ------ | ------ | 
| ![Links_widget](/uploads/e1b50cef436e9ec3104f744832463356/Links_widget.png) |![Links_expanded](/uploads/30920c5cbed250c2c65ca73a7c1eb9a1/Links_expanded.png) | ![Link_added](/uploads/facc40ee2d81da62c984fa65f2f0ea22/Link_added.png)|![Text_added-1](/uploads/654690d1ddfe3be2c329c4601483ee81/Text_added-1.png)|![Link_added-1](/uploads/2475243be52cac4999d15f2afad62767/Link_added-1.png)|

**Additional notes**
- If we detect that the link is from Slack or Zoom, we can display those icons next to the relevant link. For other links, we can use the more general [link icon](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-svgs/blob/main/sprite_icons/link.svg).  
- Permissions: the links widget will be visible to Developers+, meaning that only Developers and up can view the links, or add new ones.

### Further details

This works supports the [Incident Management](https://about.gitlab.com/direction/monitor/debugging_and_health/incident_management/) direction.

title: Rake task to reindex an index
description:
The initial iteration will be to implement a Rake task which takes a single index name as its argument, and recreates the matching index. At a high level this means:

1. Concurrently create a new index with temporary name matching the existing index definition.
1. Use `with_lock_retries` to swap the names of the new and original index in a transaction, as renaming an index takes an `ACCESS EXCLUSIVE` lock on the index (at least in PG 11).
1. Drop the original index.

Couple error cases that should be handled:

* Disallow the rake task to operate on `PRIMARY KEY` or `UNIQUE` indexes.
* Currently, if `with_lock_retries` exhausts all configured attempts to acquire the lock, it sets the `lock_timeout` to 0 and proceeds, to ensure the migration completes. Since a reindex is a non-critical operation, instead cleanup the temporary index and fail the rake task if the lock cannot be acquired.

epic.title: Automatic reindexing of standard indexes

title: Frontend: Migrate Pipeline tabs to use Vue
description:
Migrate `app/views/projects/pipelines/_with_tabs.html.haml` to `GlTabs`. Currently, we are instantiating one Vue ap per tab which adds a lot of complexity and also slows down the initial page load significantly. It also prevent us from migrating to use GlTabs component because we still userails to handle the tabs creation.

This whole work is behind the FF `pipeline_tabs_vue`

To fix all of these problems, migrating all pipeline tabs to a single Vue app will be a huge benefit. There are a lot of pieces in the pipeline page, so I have broken down the steps here:

title: BitBucket Server import using name instead of key
description:
### Summary

BitBucket Server import seems to be using the name instead of the key of the project to build the URL on where to look for the project for importing.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Have a project in BitBucket Server where the key and name are not the same.
1. In the UI, go to import screen.
1. Enter all required fields.
1. Get a list of projects.
1. Choose a project to import and click "Import" button.

### Reports

Internal links:

- 500 error: https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/165621
- 422 error: https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/164963

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

User gets an error.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

System attempts to import.

### Output of checks

GitLab.com, GitLab Enterprise Edition 13.2.0-pre df160d9f891

### Possible fixes

May be related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229901 and changes to GraphQL wrapper

## Possible Workarounds

1. Rename project name to be same as key.
1. Use the [API import option](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/import.html#import-repository-from-bitbucket-server).

epic.title: 🐞 Bitbucket Importer bugs

title: Global Search page Load Times and Goals
description: ### Overview Users are expecting that page load times should be fast. Today GitLab has perception of being slow. For Global Search how fast should the page load? 2 seconds is the generally accepted standard I have heard for years. I don't know the origin. But it comes form the Idea that "40% of People expect a page to load in 2 seconds. 40% of people won't wait for 3 seconds". I have found references to this dating back to 2003. I wouldn't be surprised if it dates back to the dawn of HTML. #### Why 2 seconds? 2 seconds is perceivably fast and I can't expect many users would complain about it being too fast. There are several scenarios where 2 seconds makes since. - The page that loads after clicking on an Add. - The page that loads after click on a search result. (drilling down) I have made an observation that what the user expects for information after the click probably correlates to how long they are willing to wait. Achieving the customers expectations is not about willingness to wait. It still needs to be relatively fast. ### A better model for page load speed expectations In order to set a goal that is meaningful a few details could help in understanding expectations. We can Apply the Fibonacci pattern to account for the time scaling to the value of information. #### Accounting for the Value or importance of the information on the page. The more detail and more interaction the user can have the larger the value. - **Homepage** these are generally top level information that contain little interactivity and little depth of information that is not going to be specific to the users current need. This would make a good baseline. We will give it a score of "1". - **Commit/code** are the core of the MR and are probably the most important most interactive page a user might use. We will give it a score of "5". - **Merge Request** adds more value then an issue but not as much as the pages where you can commit and update code. Score of 4. - **Issue** interactive and a primary source for intake and learning. Score is 3. - **Search Result pages** Not very interactive, can be valuable to find new link to new information. It is foundational to the other areas. Score of 2. ### Proposed Page Load Time expectation. Homepage as the Baseline loads in 1.36 Seconds. Search result page in order to be considered fast would be 2* baseline, or **2.72**. ### Goals by Quarter We should plan to cut the time difference in half each quarter. https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/product-enablement/product-performance-enablement?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-function=median #### Q2 FY20 - Basic Global Search Projects - 8.5 seconds - Advanced Global Search - 13.45 seconds - Advanced Global Search Code - 25.9 seconds #### Q3 FY20 Goal - Basic Global Search Projects - 4.25 seconds `(8.5- (1.36*2)) /2 + 1.36 = 4.25 ` - Advanced Global Search - 6.73 seconds `(13.45- (1.36*2)) /2 + 1.36 =6.73` - Advanced Global Search Code - 12.9 seconds `(25.9- (1.36*2)) /2 + 1.36 =12.95`

title: Reuse TCP connections between successive mailer jobs
description:
In gitlab.com SaaS, we use GCP Cloud NAT for all internet egress. We observe high NAT port utilization from sidekiq VMs, often correlating high NAT error rates (due to port exhaustion) with high rates of error in the mailers queue. We've started to suspect that the high port demand is due to TCP connection churn to gitlab.com's mail provider, as successive ActionMailer jobs might be opening and closing TCP connections.

Would it be possible to configure the mail client to reuse TCP connections between successive sidekiq jobs that run on the same sidekiq worker process, where possible? This might only be possible within each thread, but that might still make a big impact.

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/infrastructure/-/issues/10629, and issues linked there, for some more context.

title: Release asset link type and filepath are not saved when creating a new Release through the API
description:
### Summary

When creating a new release using the [Create Release API (`POST /projects/:id/releases`)](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/#create-a-release), all asset links are assigned the type `other`, even when the request body specified a different value (i.e. `runbook`, `image`, or `package`). In addition, the `direct_asset_url` exactly matches the `url` parameter, even when a custom `filepath` parameter is provided.

This bug only happens when creating a **new** release. Editing existing links using the [Release Links API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/links.html#update-a-link) works as expected.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Using the API, create a new release (`POST /projects/:id/releases`) with an asset link with a non-default type and a custom `filepath`:

   ```json
   {
     "name": "v4.2",
     "tag_name": "v4.2",
     "ref": "master",
     "description": "Version 4.2",
     "assets": {
       "links": [
         {
           "name": "An example runbook link",
           "url": "https://example.com/runbook",
           "link_type": "runbook",
           "filepath": "/permanent/path/to/runbook"
         }
       ]
     }
   }
   ```

1. A new release will be successfully created and will be returned in the API response.
1. In the API response, look at the `link_type` and `direct_asset_url` of the newly created asset link.

#### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The `link_type` is `other` (the default value). `direct_asset_url` is `https://example.com/runbook` (the same as `url`).

#### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The `link_type` should be `runbook` as specified in the request JSON. `direct_asset_url` should be `.../-/releases/v4.2/permanent/path/to/runbook`.

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com.

title: Investigate performance problems with rule html_mailto
description:
### Summary

While setting up DAST full scans for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/ we noticed that passive scan rule `html_mailto` takes a long time to execute, which causes the DAST job to time out. Unfortunately, there is no apparent way to disable this rule (e.g. via `DAST_EXCLUDE_RULES`).

It should be possible to disable this rule or to tweak its performance so that the DAST job does not time out.

Some notes from an initial investigation:
- This rule is implemented in `AutoTagRegexScanner` https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/65afe6af651cc789e96a3079edd86dd025ca8da1/zap/src/main/java/org/zaproxy/zap/extension/pscan/scanner/RegexAutoTagScanner.java. 
- This scanner loads the patterns to scan from a [config file](https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/169f349aed4c188c495804e2ddbfe40a27e1d633/zap/src/main/resources/org/zaproxy/zap/resources/config.xml#L76-L85). 
- The problem could lie in the [regex](https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/169f349aed4c188c495804e2ddbfe40a27e1d633/zap/src/main/resources/org/zaproxy/zap/resources/config.xml#L83) that is applied to response bodies, which seems not very performant.
- There is a property called [`enabled`](https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/169f349aed4c188c495804e2ddbfe40a27e1d633/zap/src/main/resources/org/zaproxy/zap/resources/config.xml#L84) which might allow us to turn off the rule.

### Steps to reproduce

Configure a full scan against GitLab or any other application that returns large responses.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/643427292#L4253

Look for log messages like this:
`Passive Scan rule html_mailto took 86 seconds to scan https://gitlab-review-ng-dast-fu-m4ht1m.gitlab-review.app/assets/webpack/monaco.9ae6ac28.chunk.js application/javascript 2549011`

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Passive rule `html_mailto` takes a long time to execute, leading to DAST jobs timing out.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Possible solutions:
- Passive rule `html_mailto` takes less time to execute
- There is an option to turn off rule `html_mailto`

cc @ngeorge1 @gitlab-org/secure/dynamic-analysis-be

title: [BE] Remove instance-level Value Stream Analytics
description:
~backend portion of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223734

### Problem to solve

With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/196455 we removed access to instance level value stream analytics from the top level navigation in favour of group level VSA. Currently VSA cannot be accessed via the navigation bar, but can be browsed to directly.

We should eliminate any remaining Instance-level VSA code to correctly reflect this.

### User experience goal

We are moving analytics features to the group level, this will help clear up any possible confusion on how to access VSA. Additionally, the additional code and tests are starting to impact developing new features.

### Proposal

* Remove the route and move the controller code/views to the group level
* Update feature specs and other related tests

title: DAST On-Demand Scans - Use existing site profiles for scans - Frontend
description:
- overview: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2912
- parent issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222755
- ~backend counterpart: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230604

## Summary

This is the ~frontend  part for creating DAST on-demand scans from existing site profiles. 

## Designs

- Figma file: https://www.figma.com/file/7CaJqOTOpPEOzkYkoU5bs5/DAST-Ondemand-Profile

| Context | Preview |
| ------ | ------ |
| Updated layout | ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-21_at_2.08.37_PM](/uploads/c1e9897358d345038f64531cd921b47c/Screen_Shot_2020-07-21_at_2.08.37_PM.png) |
| No site profiles | ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-21_at_2.07.59_PM](/uploads/a418e65b2f6187a064d83655041d46ee/Screen_Shot_2020-07-21_at_2.07.59_PM.png) |
| Site profile summary | ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-21_at_2.10.27_PM](/uploads/b7ff59c77dc1571f47c9d19f6d16bae2/Screen_Shot_2020-07-21_at_2.10.27_PM.png) |

## Implementation Plan

- [x] Update the form's layout to match the designs:
  - [x] The form should consist in 2 cards.
  - [x] The top card shows the scanner's settings (scan mode & attached branch).
  - [x] The bottom card shows site profiles' settings. Its header includes a link to the profiles library.
    - [x] The **Manage profiles** link is disabled if there are no site profiles yet.
- [x] Pass new required props down to the app:
  - [x] `profilesLibraryPath`: required to show a link to the profiles library.
  - [x] `newSiteProfileFormPath`: required to show a link to the **Site profile form**.
- [x] Trigger a GraphQL query for fetching the existing site profiles and store them in the `siteProfiles` state property. The query will be implemented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225816.
- [x] Replace the **Target URL** field with a dropdown to let users select existing site profiles.
- [x] When a site profile is selected in the dropdown, show a summary of that profile below the dropdown.
- [x] If `siteProfiles` is empty (i.e. the project doesn't contain any site profiles yet), replace the dropdown with a link to the **Site profile form**. In this case, the submit button can never be enabled.
- [x] Update the GraphQL mutation to send the required arguments (see [decisions](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222755#mutation-for-running-a-dast-scan)).
- [x] Specs:
  - ~frontend 
    - [x] The link to the profiles library is displayed properly, and it is disabled if `siteProfiles` is empty.
    - [x] The **Site profiles** field is populated properly.
    - [x] Selected site profile's summary is displayed properly.
    - [x] The **Site profile** section shows a link to the **Site profile form** when `siteProfiles` is empty.
    - [x] The GraphQL mutation is built properly.
  - ~backend 
    - [x] Include new props in `ee/app/helpers/projects/on_demand_scans_helper.rb` specs.

title: [BE] Avoid redirection in snippets for binary blobs
description:
At the moment, we have a redirection to avoid editing/updating snippets with binary blobs because we haven't implemented yet the functionality to handle them.

Nevertheless, in the VUE refactor that is being done, it will implement a [protection](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225881) to avoid sending data for these binary blobs.

This means that we can show the edit form even if the snippet has binary blobs, but only when the new VUE refactor is in place.

Therefore, we can add a check when we set the redirection and check if the `snippets_vue_edit` FF is disabled.

epic.title: Handling of binary blobs in snippets

title: [Feature flag] Enable ci_job_entry_matches_all_keys feature flag
description:
## What

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36536

Enable and remove the `:ci_job_entry_matches_all_keys` feature flag

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::continuous integration" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_ci`
- Best individual to reach out to: `@mbobin`

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Improve user error messages for wrong configured jobs.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Cross pipeline jobs(the ones that use the `trigger` keyword) might be identified as regular jobs.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

N/A

## Roll Out Steps

- [ ] Enable on staging
- [ ] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour
- [ ] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [ ] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production`
- [ ] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [ ] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [ ] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: Use Testify in all Go-based Secure project tests
description:
### Problem to solve

## Unclear test output

Secure tests currently use either [reflect.DeepEqual](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/6ac2103270164f6397c91932d989b83c06e04277/issue/issue_test.go#L436) or an [equality operator](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/6ac2103270164f6397c91932d989b83c06e04277/issue/issue_test.go#L389) to determine whether the `actual` result matches the `expected` result. Both of these comparisons will yield a wall of text when the comparison fails, for example:

```
--- FAIL: TestIssue (0.00s)
    --- FAIL: TestIssue/MarshalJSON (0.00s)
        --- FAIL: TestIssue/MarshalJSON/SAST (0.00s)
            issue_test.go:414: Wrong result. Expected:
                "{\n \"id\":
                \"1e029c1314252858f37ab31b517c4bd5e99c22eb91b9331e0ee3b65cf3b0a5853\",\n
                \"category\": \"sast\",\n \"name\": \"Possible command injection\",\n \"message\":
                \"Possible command injection\",\n \"description\": \"The ciphertext produced is
                susceptible to alteration by an adversary.\",\n \"cve\":
                \"09abf078636daa3bc6a3d49fba232774a5d9b7c454e1003e6ab12cd56938296a\",\n
                \"severity\": \"Medium\",\n \"confidence\": \"High\",\n \"solution\": \"Use the
                system(command, parameters) method which passes command line parameters safely.\",\n
                \"scanner\": {\n \"id\": \"brakeman\",\n \"name\": \"Brakeman\"\n },\n \"location\":
                {\n \"file\": \"app/controllers/application_controller.rb\",\n \"start_line\":
                831,\n \"end_line\": 832\n },\n \"identifiers\": [\n {\n \"type\": \"cve\",\n
                \"name\": \"CVE-2018-1234\",\n \"value\": \"CVE-2018-1234\",\n \"url\":
                \"https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-1234\"\n }\n ],\n
                \"links\": [\n {\n \"name\": \"Awesome-security blog post\",\n \"url\":
                \"https://example.com/blog-post\"\n },\n {\n \"url\":
                \"https://example.com/another-blog-post\"\n }\n ],\n \"scan\": {\n \"scanner\": {\n
                \"id\": \"brakeman\",\n \"name\": \"Brakeman\"\n },\n \"type\": \"sast\"\n }\n}" 

                But got:

                "{\n \"id\":
                \"e029c1314252858f37ab31b517c4bd5e99c22eb91b9331e0ee3b65cf3b0a5853\",\n
                \"category\": \"sast\",\n \"name\": \"Possible command injection\",\n \"message\":
                \"Possible command injection\",\n \"description\": \"The ciphertext produced is
                susceptible to alteration by an adversary.\",\n \"cve\":
                \"09abf078636daa3bc6a3d49fba232774a5d9b7c454e1003e6ab12cd56938296a\",\n
                \"severity\": \"Medium\",\n \"confidence\": \"High\",\n \"solution\": \"Use the
                system(command, parameters) method which passes command line parameters safely.\",\n
                \"scanner\": {\n \"id\": \"brakeman\",\n \"name\": \"Brakeman\"\n },\n \"location\":
                {\n \"file\": \"app/controllers/application_controller.rb\",\n \"start_line\":
                831,\n \"end_line\": 832\n },\n \"identifiers\": [\n {\n \"type\": \"cve\",\n
                \"name\": \"CVE-2018-1234\",\n \"value\": \"CVE-2018-1234\",\n \"url\":
                \"https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-1234\"\n }\n ],\n
                \"links\": [\n {\n \"name\": \"Awesome-security blog post\",\n \"url\":
                \"https://example.com/blog-post\"\n },\n {\n \"url\":
                \"https://example.com/another-blog-post\"\n }\n ],\n \"scan\": {\n \"scanner\": {\n
                \"id\": \"brakeman\",\n \"name\": \"Brakeman\"\n },\n \"type\": \"sast\"\n }\n}"
FAIL
exit status 1
FAIL	gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/v2/issue	0.259s
```

This makes it really difficult to understand what part of the comparison failed. If we instead switch to using [`assert.JSONeq`](https://godoc.org/github.com/stretchr/testify/assert#JSONEq), then it becomes much easier to understand the reason for the failure:

```
--- FAIL: TestIssue (0.00s)
    --- FAIL: TestIssue/MarshalJSON (0.00s)
        --- FAIL: TestIssue/MarshalJSON/SAST (0.00s)
            issue_test.go:411:
                	Error Trace:	issue_test.go:411
                	Error:      	Not equal:

                	            	Diff:
                	            	--- Expected
                	            	+++ Actual
                	            	@@ -5,3 +5,3 @@
                	            	- (string) (len=2) "id": (string) (len=65) "1e029c1314252858f37ab31b517c4bd5e99c22eb91b9331e0ee3b65cf3b0a5853",
                	            	+ (string) (len=2) "id": (string) (len=64) "e029c1314252858f37ab31b517c4bd5e99c22eb91b9331e0ee3b65cf3b0a5853",
                	            	  (string) (len=11) "identifiers": ([]interface {}) (len=1) {
                	Test:       	TestIssue/MarshalJSON/SAST
```

## Reduced boilerplate testing code

In addition to making test failure output clearer, using assertions from the [testify package](https://godoc.org/github.com/stretchr/testify/assert) will also reduce boilerplate testing code.

For example, instead of constantly inserting checks such as [the following](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/blob/6b8699da5ad515b84b21bf44b318e3c4d8057994/analyze/analyze_test.go#L97-99):

```go
if !reflect.DeepEqual(want, got) {
  t.Errorf("Wrong result. Expected:\n%#v\nbut got:\n%#v", want, got)
}
```

We can simply insert an assertion:

```
assert.Equal(t, want, got)
```

## Simplified custom matchers

This change will allow us to remove some [custom JSON Matching code](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/blob/6b8699da5ad515b84b21bf44b318e3c4d8057994/internal/testutils/testutils.go#L80-98) which can be replaced by using [`testify.JSONeq`](https://godoc.org/github.com/stretchr/testify/assert#JSONEq)

## Removal of custom sorting functions

We'll also be able to use [`assert.ElementsMatch()`](https://godoc.org/github.com/stretchr/testify/assert#ElementsMatch) to perform order-agnostic element matching, allowing us to remove a large amount of [sorting code](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/87#note_388876057) which is currently used to enforce consistency in some of our tests.

## Reduction of incorrectly written tests

Finally, using assertions will reduce the possibility of errors such as [the following](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/gitlab-depscan/-/merge_requests/12#note_374774570) from occurring and by using `github.com/stretchr/testify/require`, we can ensure that a failure will halt tests immediately, instead of needing to remember to [use t.Fatalf](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/gitlab-depscan/-/merge_requests/12#note_374759265)

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### Proposal

Update the projects to use the [testify.Assert](https://godoc.org/github.com/stretchr/testify/assert) package. 

We'll focus on Dependency Scanning first, then open follow-up issues for other groups if they are interested in following the same approach.

In particular, the unit tests for Gemnasium's dependency file parsers can be simplified, and a lot more readable. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/87/diffs#note_388789397
 
- Dependency Scanning
   1. [x] [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium)
      - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/192
   1. [x] [gemnasium-maven](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven)
      - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/117
   1. [x] [gemnasium-python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python)
      - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/merge_requests/103
   1. [x] [retire.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js)
      - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js/-/merge_requests/76
   1. [x] [bundler audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit)
      - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/merge_requests/76
   1. [x] [npm-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/npm-audit)
      - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/npm-audit/-/merge_requests/12
   1. [x] [common package](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common)
      - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/merge_requests/149

<details>
<summary>Other groups</summary>

- Container Security
   1. [ ] [klar](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar)
- Static Analysis ([already using it in some projects](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230600#note_383961792))
   1. [x] [spotbugs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs)
   1. [ ] ~~[tslint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/tslint)~~ deprecated
   1. [x] [eslint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint)
   1. [x] [kubesec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec)
   1. [x] [pmd-apex](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/pmd-apex)
   1. [x] [sobelow](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/sobelow)
   1. [x] [secrets](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets)
   1. [x] [gosec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec)
   1. [x] [nodejs-scan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan)
   1. [x] [security-code-scan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan)
   1. [ ] [phpcs-security-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/phpcs-security-audit)
   1. [x] [brakeman](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman)
   1. [x] [bandit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit)
   1. [x] [flawfinder](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/flawfinder)

</details>



### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Tests in Secure projects no longer use `reflect.DeepEqual` or plain equality operators - every comparison in a test uses an assertion from [testify](https://godoc.org/github.com/stretchr/testify/assert)

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

Yes, this will affect all secure projects

### Links / references

/cc @NicoleSchwartz @gonzoyumo @fcatteau
